field_reports.summary: NGA: Population Movement - 06-2025 - Benue - Population Movement 2025 #2 (2025-07-23)
field_reports.description:
Benue and Plateau states in Nigeria are experiencing one of the most protracted and deadly communal conflicts in West Africa. The farmer-herder conflict, rooted in land use disputes and increasingly complicated by criminal violence and impunity, has persisted for over 24 years. The intensity of recent attacks, particularly from late March to June 2025, has reached catastrophic levels.

In Benue State, 23 out of 23 LGAs have reported violent attacks. Recurrent assaults in Ukum, Logo, Gwer West, Gwer East, Katsina-Ala, Agatu, and Apa LGAs have led to the displacement of over 450,000 people (IOM Nigeria, June 2025 Displacement Matrix Report). More than 200 villages have been destroyed, with schools, health centers, boreholes, and markets deliberately targeted and rendered inoperable.

In Plateau State, between 27 March and 2 April 2025, five communities in Bokkos LGA (Daffo, Gwande, Hurti, Manguna, and Ruwi) suffered coordinated armed attacks. The Plateau Peace Building Agency confirmed that 167 rural communities have been attacked in the last two years in Bassa, Barkin Ladi, Bokkos, Jos East, Jos South, Mangu, Riyom, and Wase LGAs. Over 65,000 people have been displaced (UNOCHA Nigeria, May 2025 Situation Overview).

A notable incident occurred on June 14, 2025, when suspected herdsmen killed 200 people in Yelwata, Guma LGA (Benue) and displaced 2,000 others (Benue State Emergency Management Agency, BSEMA, June 2025). Just six days later, 32 more civilians, mostly women and children, were killed in renewed violence in Mangu and Bokkos (Plateau State Government Situation Brief, June 2025).

field_reports.summary: NGA: Other - 06-2025 - Farmers Herders Clashes/Bandit Attack
field_reports.description:
A devastating attack occurred in the Yelewata community, resulting in significant loss of life and displacement. Here's an update on the incident: Benue Communities have been under constant attacks by armed carriers. In a recent attack on Friday, 13/6/2025, hundreds of persons were displaced, many killed, and some maimed in the Yelewata community in Guma LGA.

The displaced persons are currently being registered at the Makurdi International Market to ascertain the number of displaced persons. Over 10 International and home-based CSOs are on the ground to coordinate the documentation of the affected persons as well as find a safe space for them.

Attack Details

· Date: June 13/14, 2025

· Location: Yelewata community, Guma LGA, Benue State

· Attackers: Suspected armed herders/Fulani terrorists

· Casualties: Estimated 100-200 people killed, with many still missing, and over 120 reported missing

· Displacement: Over 2,000 people were displaced due to the attack

· Injuries: Many individuals were injured, receiving treatment at Benue State University Teaching Hospital (BSUTH) in Makurdi

field_reports.description: With the prediction from the Nigeria Metereological Agency (NIMET) on the flood alerts in about 30 states in Nigeria, this has continue to manifest with flood affecting about 13 states already.  Several houses and properties have been destroyed and about 20 people dead.  The flood has already affected states like Borno, Ondo, Ekiti, Delta, Nasarawa, Kebbi, Akwa Ibom, Cross River, Rivers, Kogi, Niger, Kwara, Ogun.

On 29 June 2025, at about 12:46 pm, there was a heavy rainfall in the Wovi community, the Garjang community, and Gumsun town in Damboa LGA, which led to the destruction of properties, resulting in 9 fatalities and 18 people sustained injuries.  Many houses were damaged, prompting a swift response from emergency services to assess the situation and provide humanitarian services to the affected residents.

o 153 confirmed deaths, with more unaccounted for.

o 213 reported injuries.

o 1,590 individuals displaced from their homes.

o Over 100 peoples missing ( Still counting )

o Over 3,018 people directly affected.

o Significant psychosocial trauma, particularly among women and children.

According to the latest update from the assessment conducted by the joint teams of National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), the Nigerian Red Cross, Society, International Organization for Migration (IOM), Niger State Emergency Management Agency (NSEMA), 3018 people were affected, 1590 people were displaced, 162 casualties, and 151 death recorded. 2 roads were damaged and 3 bridges destroyed.

2 roads were damaged, and 265 buildings destroyed.

The team has been engaged in the search & rescue operations, and distribution of food items to 200 households.

As a result of a heavy rainfall that began at about 3 am and fell for several hours while people were still sleeping in Kpege, Mokwa local government, about 50 houses were submerged, and hectares of farmland were destroyed.  A total number of bodies have been recovered and confirmed dead, with about 45 injured and receiving attention.  Red Cross volunteers have been involved in search and rescue operations and first aid assistance to the wounded.

There is a possibility of recording more deaths as search and rescue operations are still ongoing, and many residents remain unaccounted for.

field_reports.description:
There has been displacement in some communities in Isa LGA in Sokoto state as a result of an ultimatum issued by one of the OAG leaders to leave the communities on the allegation that they are providing information to the government forces.
Since early 2022, Isa LGA has witnessed a dangerous increase in armed insurgent activity. Recently, the leader of one of the AOG issued a violent ultimatum to Bafarawa village, warning residents to evacuate within 48 hours or face attack. This marks a pattern of threats and violence similar to previous assaults in neighboring areas. 
Several Villages are affected by the attacks, including Makira, Shabanza, Katsalle, Dan Kura, Garin Tunkiya, Dama, Dan Tazako I, II, and III, Gaugai, and several others.
Humanitarian Impact 

Displacement:
Thousands of families have been forced to flee, with many now taking refuge in overcrowded IDP camps. These makeshift shelters lack food, clean water, clothing, sanitation, and medical care. Families are living in open spaces, mosques, schools, and markets, exposing them to weather extremes and heightened security risks.

Sexual Violence:
Numerous incidents of rape, especially of underage girls and married women—have been reported during night-time attacks. Survivors remain without access to trauma counseling, reproductive healthcare, or legal aid.

Health Crises:
All health centers have either been burned or abandoned. Diseases such as malaria, diarrhea, respiratory infections, and urinary tract infections are widespread. Vaccines are unavailable due to the collapse of cold-chain systems, and essential drugs are scarce. Pregnant women and children under five are particularly vulnerable.

Food Insecurity:
Farms have been deserted, food stocks looted, and markets shut down due to fear and insecurity. There is no food assistance in any affected area, increasing the risk of mass starvation.

field_reports.description:
The communal crisis between Ilobu, Ifon-Osun, and Erin-Osun in Irepodun and Orolu Local government areas of Osun State, is an agelong one that started over 100 years ago on the land and boundary disagreement reoccurred on the 19th March 2025 which resulted in significant humanitarian needs. The Nigerian Red Cross Society has supported the Government through the State Emergency Management Agency to respond to the crisis. In the recent crisis which started on 19 March 2025 several homes and businesses set ablaze, forcing many women and children to flee.

According to the assessment by the Nigerian Red Cross, there are:

1. Damage and Destruction: Widespread destruction of homes, businesses, and infrastructure was observed. Specifically, over 700 houses were burnt in the three towns during the incidents, resulting in significant loss of property and livelihoods Over 83 shops, 3 mosques, 5 Schools, and 4 churches were also burnt, exacerbating the humanitarian crisis.

2. Businesses Affected: Thousands of businesses, including small-scale enterprises and market stalls, were affected, leading to loss of income and livelihoods for many individuals and families.

3. Displacement: Over 5000 individuals and families were displaced, with some taking refuge in the IDP camps set up by the State Government and closed state.

4. Injuries and Fatalities: Reports of deaths, degrees of injuries, and fatalities were confirmed, with some individuals already receiving medical attention.

field_reports.description: A tanker conveying gasoline crashed, and the company brought another truck with a generator to transfer the product with a crowd gathered around the area, some were scooping fuel while others were capturing the event with their phones,  this eventually resulted in an explosion which affected many casualties around the area.

The tanker explosion occurred in the early hours of Saturday 18 January 2025, when an attempt was being made to transfer from a crashed oil tanker into another truck using a generator, the fuel transfer sparked an explosion leading to the death of those transferring the gasoline and bystanders.

The blast claimed many lives because a crowd had gathered at the scene, including those taking pictures and those attempting to scoop gasoline.

field_reports.description: Two boats collided in the Amuwo Odofin area of Lagos state.  The 2 boats were carrying 16 passengers each before the coalition. The event occurred on Monday 07 October 2024 in the middle of the lagoon near Imore town. 11 passengers were rescued with various degrees of injuries, while 21 passengers were brought out and confirmed dead.

Summary report of flood disaster
The rain started around 2 pm yesterday 4/10/2024 and lasted until 11:30 pm. 10 communities were affected such as

1. Itanla
2. Akinjise
3. Ajilo
4. Adesuper
5. Elewuro
6. Gani Fawehinmi
7. Fagun
8. Oke-odunwo
9. New Town
10. Lipakala
11. Laje

 About 3021 households were affected, about 28 vehicles were submerged, more than 300 shops were affected, and properties like generators, fridges, machines, fish feeds, fish ponds, and other household materials were lost to the flood. Properties worth Millions were destroyed with farmland of vegetables. NEMA and SEMA joined Red Cross volunteers in Ondo Ondo West for impact assessment today 5/10/2024. The causes are. Government has orderd immediate evacuation of affected residents and launching rapid response efforts to mitigate further damage.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Civil Unrest - 08-2024 - Protest Against bad governance
field_reports.description:
*Nassarawa.  The situation is calm in the state capital. The political office burnt down.  However, it was chaotic at Keffi and Mararaba Abuja Road.
*Yobe: protesters attacked the Nigerian Red Cross Society Potiskum Divisional Office, the office was vandalized with protesters carting away air conditioners and other properties,  and the Red Cross operational vehicles were burnt down.

*Kebbi: Some protesters March towards the govt house to deliver their message, the governor or came out to meet with them but the security advised against that so he went back. Police then dispersed the protesters with teargas.
In Jega LGA, the protest was peaceful until some persons believed to be hired thugs destroyed Jega central roundabout and looted bread and some foodstuff at an open market.

*In Niger State A total of Five 5 people lost their lives today (01-08-2024) in the Suleja metropolis of Suleja LGA of Niger State when Security Agents shot sporadically to disperse Protesters who were trying to break into "A" Division Police station in Suleja town and also those that blocked Abuja-Kaduna expressway.In Tafa LGA also of Niger State, some of the protesters forced their way into the Local Gov't secretariat, Looted and set ablaze some official vehicles packed at the Secretariat premises.

*Gombe: Vandalization and destruction of vehicles in Emir palace, All other local government areas of the state are relatively calm. Other Than Gombe local government headquarters where vandalization was witnessed, snatching of phones and valuables.

*Kano: Emergency Preparedness and Response Protest in Kano
Murtala Muhammad Specialist Hospital casualty figures 
No of wounded 33
No of Death 06

The number of fatalities is unquantifiable 
Many victims were not reported  or were taken to undisclosed locations or bodies identified by relation
HCiD
Ambulances were burnt and vandalized 
Fire Engines burnt and vandalized  exact number will be revealed later after verification
Presently a 24-hour curfew has been imposed by the the state government.

*Delta Protest was peaceful in many parts of the state but later turned violent with the police firing tear gas to bring the situation under control.
*Bayelsa witness mild clashes.
*Borno: In the early hours of Thursday morning there was a detonation of improvised explosive devices which led to the death of 16 persons while several others were critically injured and on admission across various Government hospitals in the state. A 24-hour curfew was imposed by the state government to bring the situation under control.


*Plateau: The protest was peaceful. In the Jos metropolitan area, a group of peaceful protesters gathered around the Secretariat junction area of Jos South. The protesters comprised some key state stakeholders and youths. There are no forms ANY violence.

*Jigawa between 6:00 am and 10:00 pm, protesters vandalized government stores and other facilities as well as looting many properties, targeting government assets, and removing valuable materials. Metal barriers were removed and government buildings and offices of the political parties were set on fire. 4 people died and many injured casualties were taken to hospital in different locations in the state.

*Katsina: Clashes ensued between the security forces and the protesters as the latter tried to storm the government house. Security personnel employed tear gas fired shots into the air and used hot water cannons to disperse the protesters and quell the unrest.

Despite the measures taken by the security forces, the situation remained tense as protesters and security personnel faced off. The protest, which began as a peaceful demonstration, highlighted the growing frustration among the youth over governance issues in Nigeria. 

 *FCT. The anti-protesters started attacking the protesters at Gwagwalada and soldiers had to step in and throw tear gas to chase everyone away. But some peaceful protesters are still there

The protesters at MKO Abiola stadium were asked to go into the stadium but they refused so the police threw tear gas at them. Same thing at the Secretariat. Some boys were caught with knives trying to attack the protesters at Eagle Square. Violence was recorded along Nyanya, Mararraba Rd  Dutse/Bwari Road.

Kaduna Day 1: 

Between 8:30 am and 11:00 am, protesters were actively looting and vandalizing properties, targeting government assets, and removing valuable materials. Metals are being pulled out, and damage is being inflicted on properties. 

No casualties have been reported within the vicinity so far. However, an unconfirmed report indicates a police officer was shot around 44/Government House.

Armed police, soldiers, and civil defense personnel were present in the area.

Between 12:00pm and 1:45pm, an unidentified youth with a bullet wound received First Aid from the Branch stand by team and was transported to Barau Dikko Teaching Hospital for immediate medical attention.

During monitoring around 44 Army Reference Hospital/ Government House around the same time, the team was informed that casualties were evacuated, but the exact number remains undisclosed.

Later this afternoon,  another youth was shot but his current remain unknown due to lack of access as a result of the shootout. 

Office belonging to Kaduna State Traffic Law Enforcement Agencies (KASTLEA) along Government Road was set ablaze and government properties as well as ceased motorcycles, KEKE NEPEP among other office valuables were LOOTED by the protesters. 

Kaduna Day 2
Security in Kaduna metropolis remains fluid after yesterday's protest and attack on government house. Below is a situational reports on selected suburbs and city centre as at today 2nd August, 2024_

 Barnawa: Barnawa remains calm and few private vehicles seen moving. Security personnel dominate the Barnawa Complex area.

 Trikania/ Nassarawa: There were protesters along the use to be busy Nnamdi Azikiwe Expressway yesterday. Despite the huge numbers, the only threat was reported cases of thugs in Trikania collecting valuables and phones from people. This morning Trikania is calm and Nassarawa is also calm with few vehicles along the express. Expect the rail area to be blocked during prayers today in Trikania.

 Agwa/Kudenda: The threat of any kind of protest here remains very low, but could suffer from spill over of any disturbance along the express if Trikania nor Nassarawa goes south.

 Sabon-Tasha: Sabon-Tasha market area is generally quite with many stalls close. Armed security personnel are stationed around the bridge area, and market. Down to refinery junction is generally quite with very little commercial activities visible. Ungwan-Pama, Ungwan-Sunday, Ungwan- Bulus, Ungwan-Boro, Television, and Ungwan-Yelwa are calmed with few pedestrian movement and bikes in their allays.

 Badiko/44 Barracks and Hospital/Government House: This was the scene of the police and protesters clash yesterday. Heavily armed military and police dominate this area, with a sense of an uneasy calm.

Karatudu and Ungwa Romi: These two adjacent areas are calm. Few pedestrian seen moving around, and motorcycle. Protest probability here is slim.

 Tudun-wada/ Ungwan Mu'azu/Kabala West: This areas remained calm, with very few vehicular activities in them. Any protest around these areas may degenerates into a hijack by thugs and hoodlums. The security presence here is on red alert.

Gonin/Gora Area: Area is relatively calm at Gonin gora market area and people remain indoors, Few shops opened and No vehicular movement at Kaduna - Abuja road ,Ungwan  Doma, Buwaya, Ungwan Bije, and Kakau people are going on with their normal activities for now. Heavy military presence along Abuja-Kaduna express way. A scene of many previous protests and attacks on commuters.

Narayi/Karji/Kamazo: From the Narayi area of Kaduna to Karji area dominated by students, and Kamazo, there is no real threat of any protest here for now. The road looks deserted with more pedestrians walking around and few bikes, and private vehicles.

 Kawo/ Mando: Despite the huge turn out of protesters yesterday, Kawo didn't witness any disturbance. While Mando was quite. The huge numbers of security formations and barracks here makes rapid response faster in the case of eventualities.

 Central Market and Kaduna City Centre: This was an area with huge tension yesterday with thousands of people protesting yet there was no incidence of breakdown of law and order. 

 Down Quarter/Kakuri/Kurmin Gwari:  Calm and no threat of violence with few pedestrians and motor cyclists moving round, and majorly shops located within residential homes opened.

 Ungwan-Rimi/ Malali/Kabala Doki:  Protesters took to the streets of Ungwan-Rimi yesterday around Kaduna State University and Kaduna Polytechnic with no incidence of violence. This morning is calm and empty streets. Only pedestrian movement and flash of private vehicles.

 Notes 

 Elements of the Islamic Movement of Nigeria (IMN) are believed to have joined the protesters and other groups who coordinated the attacks on Kaduna State Government House and KASTLEA ZONE 3 OFFICE AND KADIPA on 1st August. 

*Lagos: Protest has been peaceful so far but pockets of clashes between protesters and security agencies are being recorded in some areas.

 Tudun-wada/ Ungwan Mu'azu/Kabala West: This areas remained calm, with very few vehicular activities in them. Any protest around these areas may degenerates into a hijack by thugs and hoodlums. The security presence here is on red alert.

Gonin/Gora Area: Area is relatively calm at Gonin gora market area and people remain indoors, Few shops opened and No vehicular movement at Kaduna - Abuja road ,Ungwan  Doma, Buwaya, Ungwan Bije, and Kakau people are going on with their normal activities for now. Heavy military presence along Abuja-Kaduna express way. A scene of many previous protests and attacks on commuters.

Narayi/Karji/Kamazo: From the Narayi area of Kaduna to Karji area dominated by students, and Kamazo, there is no real threat of any protest here for now. The road looks deserted with more pedestrians walking around and few bikes, and private vehicles.

 Kawo/ Mando: Despite the huge turn out of protesters yesterday, Kawo didn't witness any disturbance. While Mando was quite. The huge numbers of security formations and barracks here makes rapid response faster in the case of eventualities.

 Central Market and Kaduna City Centre: This was an area with huge tension yesterday with thousands of people protesting yet there was no incidence of breakdown of law and order. 

 Down Quarter/Kakuri/Kurmin Gwari:  Calm and no threat of violence with few pedestrians and motor cyclists moving round, and majorly shops located within residential homes opened.

 Ungwan-Rimi/ Malali/Kabala Doki:  Protesters took to the streets of Ungwan-Rimi yesterday around Kaduna State University and Kaduna Polytechnic with no incidence of violence. This morning is calm and empty streets. Only pedestrian movement and flash of private vehicles.

 Notes 

 Elements of the Islamic Movement of Nigeria (IMN) are believed to have joined the protesters and other groups who coordinated the attacks on Kaduna State Government House and KASTLEA ZONE 3 OFFICE AND KADIPA on 1st August. 

*Lagos: Protest has been peaceful so far but pockets of clashes between protesters and security agencies are being recorded in some areas.

field_reports.description: 42 have been confirmed dead while about 108 persons are missing
As at 04 October 2024 additional 6 dead bodies were recovered bringing the total number of dead to 42.

According to the Niger State Emergency Management Agency, a boat accident occurred on the evening of October 1, 2024, around 8:30 pm. The mishap took place on the River Niger, upstream of the Jebba dam, near Gbajibo Community in Mokwa Local Government Area. The boat that was sailing from Mundi Community to Gbajibo for a Maulid celebration with over 200 passengers at about 8:30 pm on River Niger upstream Jebba Dam when the incident occurred. About 163 people were rescued alive, while about 16 dead passengers mostly women and children were also recovered.

The Alau dam bank suffered leakages due to high rainfall leading to floods in most communities along riverine and flood-prone areas.

Impact:
•    24 deaths
•    16 LGAs affected
•    163 severely injured
•    122,330 households displaced
•    12 major roads, primarily in the northern parts of the state. 
•    60 culverts have been washed away
•    52,035 houses have been destroyed
•    178 electric poles have collapsed
•    11,183 livestock lost

A total number of 2446  households, about 14676 individuals, have been displaced in Ilaje LG due to the ocean surge due to the persistent rainfall and submerged about 1750 buildings. The communities affected are Ayetoro, Abereke, Awoye, Mese and Dagira.  The persistent ocean surge has affected the communities' daily livelihood, causing disruptions in education as well. Displaced individuals have had to relocate and stay with

On 30th August 2024

Flooding occurred in 9 LGAs in Yobe State and a series of Mud houses have been reported to collapse in Tarmuwa, Gulani, Jakusko, Nguru, Potiskum, and Nangere towns following non-stop heavy rainfall in the region.

The affected communities have sought refuge in government facilities including local schools.

The rainfall pattern observed in Yobe may continue intermittently with cloud formation persisting indicating the likelihood of further precipitation.

The flood has also washed away farm produce of Gulani LGA leaving all the farmers in distress,   

On 31st August 2024

The bridge at Jumbam community of Bursari LGA linking 9(Nine) LGAs Machine, Nguru, Karasuwa, Bade, Jakusko, Yusufari, Geidam, Yunusari and Bursari has cut off.

Leaving Commuters in distress with an alternative route of Hadeja in Jigawa State which is also not motorable.

Heavy downpours in Shuwa, Madagali LGA which resulted in flooding affecting the following communities, Mayowandu, Lumadu, Kwanmbula, Dagali, Maradi, Kirchinga, Shuwari, Duhu, Jamili, Zhau, Pallam.

The flood in Madagali LGA occurred on Wednesday, August 21, an earlier one had taken place on August 20 in Shelleng LGA of Adamawa State when the Kiri Dam in Tudun Tsira overflowed its banks, resulting in severe flooding across communities, which included Kwakwambe, Lure, Nbalang, Imburu, and Bare in neighbouring Numan Local Government Area, Kwakwambe, Lure, Nbalang

Lumadu Primary School and many other IDP camps

According to a source, “A canoe with about forty passengers capsized on the Dundaye River in the Wamakko local government area of the state.

“The victims, who are primarily women and children, were on their way to their farms across the river when the accident happened.

About 25 of the passengers who had earlier been reported missing were later confirmed dead.

10,211 people directly have been displaced 33 people have been confirmed dead and over 10,211 families have been displaced due to severe flooding in Jigawa State.

The affected community need immediate intervention of Food and non-food items

Wurukum community, Logo !, Low-Level Community, Nenger community, Idye Community, Madonna Hospital Community, Kighir Village. 

On 20th June around 11 pm, it started pouring heavily and didn’t stop till the next morning. A significant part of Makurdi, including some areas near us, is currently flooded.  The rains which started around 11pm of 20th June, 2024 lasted till nest morning of 21st June. Most residents practically kept vigil scooping water out of their rooms but the more they scooped the more the water flooded as there was no good way for the water to flow. 

Some of the affected areas are Logo 1, Wurukum community, Nenger-Idye community, Low-level community, Kighir Village, Madonna Hospital Community Isheyer-Bakurt road etc.  

 

It’s quite a situation as many streets are totally submerged. We're trying to stay updated with the local authorities for any alerts or instructions.

On the morning of 24th June, following heavy rainfall, the Trademore Estate and its surrounding estates (Efab, Pyakassa road, Sahara, Promenade) experienced a flood disaster with many buildings(mostly the buildings towards the estate gate) submerged up to window level, including a police station, pharmacies, schools, shops, and residential buildings. The access roads connecting the estates and the exit gate of the Trademore estate were overrun with flood water thereby disrupting the flow of traffic.  The flooding in the estate has been a perennial occurrence every rainy season which made the FCDA plan for the

demolition of some structures in the estate which was disrupting the natural water flow. The demolition was halted when those residing in the estate protested and got a court ruling to stop the demolition stating that the recurrent flooding in the estate was largely caused by the channeling of water into Trademore by the adjoining estates.

These estates are built on the flood plains along the river channel that runs adjacent the estate and also indiscriminate dumping of refuse in the already narrow water channel are a contributing factor to the flood. It is also important to note that there is a dam upstream from which water is released at intervals. 

Annually, this area experiences flood, some severe and some are mild. This is due to its geographical location – closeness to a river.

During the Assessment after the water receded:

It was noted that there is a school with up to 500 students including their teachers and management on the flood plain. The school management was advised to relocate the school to a safer

· ground for the sake of their safety.

· It was noted that some houses are still sitting on waterways

· Some structures earlier demolished by the Department of Development Control were being rebuilt.

· The houses affected by the flood today were part of the structures marked for demolition last year.

· The floodwater flows Gaduwa through Efab – Galadimawa - Pyakassa – Trademore and they all experienced flooding today.

· No one was reported missing or dead

· Dearth of drainage channels

· The culvert  is not wide enough to carry the volume of floodwater  passing through it

· The police station has been abandoned since last year after the flood

· The inhabitants have no early warning system in place.

There are no warning signs to alert people that the area is flood prone.

According to Nimet prediction of a 3 DAYS DOWN POOR, STARTING FROM WEDNESDAY, THE 3RD OF JULY, 2024, IT RAINED HEAVILY ON WEDNESDAY AND THERE WAS FLASH FLOOD IN 14 LGAS IN LAGOS STATE.

The resulting flooding brought down a two-storey building in the Mushin area of Lagos, grounded vehicular movement on the roads and overwhelmed thousands of residents while pupils could not attend schools in parts of the states.

MUSHIN ,AGEGE ,ALIMOSHO,ETI-OSA, L/ISLAND ,L/MAINLAND, OSHODI-ISOLO, APAPA, AMUWO-ODOFIN, IFAKO-IJAIYE, IKORODU,KOSOFE,OJO were seriously affected.

field_reports.description:
More than 170 people have been killed and about 100 others wounded after an overturned fuel tanker exploded in Jigawa, northwestern Nigeria. The crash on Tuesday night took place on an expressway in Jigawa state. People then rushed to the vehicle to collect the fuel, crowds had gathered round the overturned tanker to scoop fuel in Majiya, Jigawa state before it exploded.

Many villagers came to the scene and tried to scoop up the spilled petrol. Within minutes, a fire started and an explosion followed.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Fire - 04-2024 - Tanker accident Fire Explosion
field_reports.description:
The incident occurred as a result of reckless driving by a truck vehicle driver which led to a collision with a tanker vehicle loaded with PMS. The collision was said to have caused the PMS to spill on the road which led to the fire outbreak.

During the assessment counted a total of 70 vehicles were burnt beyond recognition.
The total number of 200 casualties were affected with 135 dead and 65 injured. many affected persons scampered for their lives,  and 4 dead bodies were burnt to ashes including a pregnant woman.
The FRSC bagged and evacuated the 4 corpses to the military hospital.
The inferno was rapidly put out by indorama fire service men who also deployed one of their earth-moving equipment to assist in removing other burnt vehicles obstructing the free flow of traffic on the highway.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Chemical Emergency - 04-2024 - Heavy Metal Poisoning #2 (2024-05-09)
field_reports.description:
Below are Epidemiological summary of Sokoto and Zamfara States as at 5th May 2024

Sokoto ;

An outbreak of heavy metal poisoning in Sokoto state was first reported on the 20th of March 2024 from Isa LGA. Patients reported with abdominal distension, abdominal pain, vomiting, fever and difficulty in breathing. Majority of the cases were children and young adults. Active search for cases by the state rapid response team, revealed cases from five additional LGAs (Illela, Sabon Birni, Tambuwal, Gwadabawa, and Dange Shuni). Of the five LGAs only Sabon Birni shares border with Isa LGA. mostly among children and young adults in Isa Local Government Area (LGA). A total of 422 cases have been reported with 29 deaths (CFR:6.9%). Illela and Tambuwal LGAs reported fewer cases but with higher CFR of 22% and 17% respectively. About half (49.8%) of the children were from households whose parents’ occupation is farming. Blood and ascetic fluid samples from cases showed high levels of Chromium, Cadmium, Cobalt, Arsenic and lead. Water samples from open wells and boreholes showed high levels of lead with significant amount of cadmium and chromium from the wells and borehole respectively. Soil samples from farm, open well and boreholes showed high concentration of Cadmium and significant level of lead. Samples
from water melon leave, fruits and tomato fruits showed very high concentration of lead.
 
The outbreak is still ongoing. It peaked in week 13 and decreased sharply in weeks 14 to 18. As at
02/05/2024, a total of 422 cases have been reported with 27 deaths (CFR:6.5%). Majority of the cases are the 0-20 years’ age group (figs 3 & 4). There is no significant difference among the male and female gender of the cases. Blood, water, environmental, food and ascetic fluid samples were collected for investigation.The blood sample results revealed high level of multiple heavy metals. The result of the water also revealed high levels of the heavy metals

Zamfara:
Zamfara reported an unidentified health condition (cases) through the LGA-DSNOs of Maradun and Shinkafi Local Government Areas on the 29th of Feb 2024.  These conditions manifested with epistaxis, abdominal swelling and pain, visible abdominal Wall veins, gross ascites, fever, and generalized body weaknesses with or without vomiting.   The affected LGAs are Anka, Shinkafi and Maradun. A total of 177 cases have been reported with a total of 3 deaths with CFR of 1.7%. as of  4thMay, 2024. Maradun and Shinkafi LGAs accounts for 98% of the cases number in the state.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Chemical Emergency - 04-2024 - Heavy Metal Poisoning
field_reports.description:
Heavy metals including cadmium, chromium, lead, and mercury are emitted mainly into the air as a result of various industrial activities including mining especially where regulation is poor. This also contributes to the deposition and build-up in soils. Heavy metals can also contaminate water sources and get into plants if they persist in the soil. Exposure to heavy metals either through the air (dust), soil, plants or water are associated with kidney, brain, liver, and bone damage including cancers of the body depending on the type of heavy metals. Persons most at risk or vulnerable include pregnant women (the unborn babies), infants and children, illegal / artisanal miners, industrial workers etc. Some of the effects of heavy metals are immediate while many will take a long time to manifest.

18 April 2024 | Abuja- NCDC Convenes an Emergency Meeting with Sokoto and Zamfara States to Address Unknown Illness

The Director General (DG) of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC), Dr Jide Idris, hosted an emergency meeting with two Honourable Commissioners for Health from Sokoto and Kaduna States on April 16, 2024 at NCDC’s Headquarters Abuja and also spoke on telephone with Zamfara’s State Commissioner for Health to unravel the cause as well as contain and mitigate the impact of the ongoing incidents of unknown origin in both Sokoto and Zamfara States. The Honourable Commissioners (Hajiya Asabe Balarabe, Dr. Aisha Anka and Hajiya Umma Ahmed) discussed the current situation, provided updates on response efforts, and agreed with the DG of NCDC on further measures to contain and mitigate the impact of the illness suspected to be heavy metal poisoning possibly linked to mining activities.

As at the 18th of April 2024, a total of 196 suspected cases of the unknown illness with seven (7) deaths have been reported across Isa, Sabon Birni, and Ilella Local Government Areas (LGAs) of Sokoto State. Results of the analyses on the various samples sent to the different sister laboratories including NIPRID, NAFDAC and NIMR are being awaited.

Following reports of similar cases in Zamfara State, another National Rapid Response Team (NRRT) will be deployed this week to assess the situation and provide support to the state.

This also contributes to the deposition and build-up in soils. Heavy metals can also contaminate water sources and get into plants if they persist in the soil. Exposure to heavy metals either through the air (dust), soil, plants or water are associated with kidney, brain, liver, and bone damage including cancers of the body depending on the type of heavy metals. Persons most at risk or vulnerable include pregnant women (the unborn babies), infants and children, illegal / artisanal miners, industrial workers etc. Some of the effects of heavy metals are immediate while many will take a long time to manifest.

18 April 2024 | Abuja- NCDC Convenes an Emergency Meeting with Sokoto and Zamfara States to Address Unknown Illness

The Director General (DG) of the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC), Dr Jide Idris, hosted an emergency meeting with two Honourable Commissioners for Health from Sokoto and Kaduna States on April 16, 2024 at NCDC’s Headquarters Abuja and also spoke on telephone with Zamfara’s State Commissioner for Health to unravel the cause as well as contain and mitigate the impact of the ongoing incidents of unknown origin in both Sokoto and Zamfara States. The Honourable Commissioners (Hajiya Asabe Balarabe, Dr. Aisha Anka and Hajiya Umma Ahmed) discussed the current situation, provided updates on response efforts, and agreed with the DG of NCDC on further measures to contain and mitigate the impact of the illness suspected to be heavy metal poisoning possibly linked to mining activities.

As at the 18th of April 2024, a total of 196 suspected cases of the unknown illness with seven (7) deaths have been reported across Isa, Sabon Birni, and Ilella Local Government Areas (LGAs) of Sokoto State. Results of the analyses on the various samples sent to the different sister laboratories including NIPRID, NAFDAC and NIMR are being awaited.

Following reports of similar cases in Zamfara State, another National Rapid Response Team (NRRT) will be deployed this week to assess the situation and provide support to the state.

field_reports.description:
In the early hours of yesterday evening, unexpected herder attacks led to an alarming loss of lives and injuries. More than 40 innocent people lost their lives while many others suffered severe physical injuries. The scene was chaotic and heart-wrenching, with locals scrambling for their lives and safety.

The hostile activities didn't stop at mere bloodshed; they escalated further into extensive displacement. Families were forced out from their homes with immediate effect due to fear and unpredictability sparked by these violent occurrences. Infrastructure was damaged as well, contributing further to the bleak scenario unfolding here.

At present, local law enforcement agencies are on high alert to prevent any further violence or destruction of property. They're also laboring relentlessly to apprehend the culprits behind this horrific act while lending as much assistance as possible to those affected.

It is crucial that we pool our resources together during such challenging times to provide relief measures for the victims who have been displaced from their homes amidst this turmoil. Your support will be invaluable in delivering immediate aid regarding food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies.

field_reports.description:
According to the Information received for the Divisional secretary of Ukum division crisis broke out after kidnap, murder of deadly militia leader by rival gang in the Ukum LGA of Benue State

According to report, over 45 persons including a family of seven feared death following the invasion of Gbagir community in the Ukum LGA by suspected Fulani militia men who according to report are been supported by another Tiv arm gang in the Ukum LGA. The report review that this was a fight to oust another Tiv militia gang in the area.

It was gather that most of the dead were members of the rival militia gangs while about 12 innocent farmers were caught in the cross fire which also left over 30 persons injured and many others are declared missing.

According to information, the bloody fight started on Tuesday morning after a Tiv militia leader in the Ukum LGA kidnapped another Fulani militia leader and his family members from the neighboring Chinkai community in the Wukari LGA of Taraba State. Though after a ransom of about N5million was given the gang leaders stills his hostages. And accordingly the killing of the hostage sparked outrage among his gang members in the Taraba State.

According to information, the combined forces of Fulani and Tiv militia gangs started moving into the bushes of Gbagir in their hundreds from Sunday to sack the gang that killed Alhaji Gana the Fulani militia leader from Taraba State. And on Tuesday morning the bloody fight ensued. And from the information gathered over 45 persons who were mainly bandits have been killed and though over 12 farmers were caught in the cross fire and over 30 persons were injured and others are reported missing, and another information has it that the two gangs are evacuating some of their dead members.

Information also review that caught in the cross fire is a family of seven in Tse Adzandeh Mbasaa, Mbajiga, Ityuluv, Torov council ward of Ukum LGA. It was gathered that the Governor of Benue State have alerted the military for swift action.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Other - 02-2024 - HERDERS ATTACKED IN THE UKUM LGA OF BENUE STATE
field_reports.description:
It is with a heavy heart that I write to inform you about the unfortunate event that has recently taken place in our homeland, specifically, in the Ukum Local Government Area (LGA) of Benue State

There was a sudden and brutal attack by herders which resulted in many casualties. The reports we have received so far are quite distressing - over 30 people have been reportedly killed and more than 10 others seriously injured

The aftermath of these attacks has led to an unprecedented displacement crisis as well, forcing over 40,000 residents from their homes. This situation is truly heartbreaking and requires urgent attention from all quarters. It's imperative for the authorities to step up security measures in vulnerable areas while also providing necessary aid to those displaced.

At present, we are trying to gather as much help as we can. Efforts are being made by local authorities and organizations alike to provide immediate assistance and relief measures for those affected by this tragedy, but there is so much more that needs to be done.

As always, thank you for your time and interest in hearing about what's happening here. We greatly appreciate any help you may be able to provide and look forward to hearing from you soon.

Note: We are still monitoring the situation and detail of the report which shall include the number of displaced persons and the locations were they are currently been camp or staying will be share to you in due course.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Other - 02-2024 - HERDERS ATTACKS IN THE IMANA-IKOBI, ADIJAH-UGBOKPO IN APA LGA OF BENUE STATE #3 (2024-02-16)
field_reports.description:
Herders attack in the Apa LGA.  A group of herders launched a devastating attack on the Imana-Ikobi community within the Apa LGA of Benue State. It is with a heavy heart that I report the loss of approximately 4 people during the attack on the 14th February, 2024 with numerous others suffering from injuries of varying severity. Meanwhile, another different attack occurred on the 15th of February 2024 around 3:pm in the daytime. Suspected Fulani herders invaded and attacked the Adijah community in Ugbokpo council ward of Apa LGA of Benue State along Oweto – Otupkpo road. According to reports the attackers opened fire on the residents and killed an unspecified number of persons, and most of the residents have fled to other nearby communities for safety. 

This sudden act of violence has shaken us to our core, bringing about a wave of grief and fear within the community. Many families are mourning while others are desperately hoping their loved ones will recover swiftly from their injuries.

At present, we are trying to gather as much help as we can. Efforts are being made by local authorities and organizations alike to provide immediate assistance and relief measures for those affected by this tragedy, but there is so much more that needs to be done.

According to the report over 10, 500 persons  have been displaced due to the current renewed conflict in the Apa LGA 

As always, thank you for your time and interest in hearing about what's happening here. We greatly appreciate any help you may be able to provide and look forward to hearing from you soon.

homes as the situation is very tense, information also confirmed that women and children have deserted their homes.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Population Movement - 02-2024 - MOVEMENT DISPLACEMENT FOR FEAR OF ATTACKS BY HERDERS
field_reports.description:
There's an alarming situation developing in the Gwer LGA and Kwande LGA, Benue State. It's come to my knowledge that there has been a mass displacement movement among the community members due to fear of impending attacks by local herders.
 
According to report from the divisional secretary of the Nigerian Red Cross Benue State Branch has it that over a week now the community members have be moving out of their community for fear of attack from the Fulani Herders whose number is increasing daily in the community. According to information some of the displaced persons are  moving to  LGA Headquarters for safety.
 
The tension escalated rapidly over the last few days, creating a sense of insecurity within the community circle. The residents are now leaving their homes and seeking refuge elsewhere for their safety, leading to a sudden exodus that is disturbing as well as heart-wrenching.
 
It seems that despite attempts from local authorities at maintaining peace, they have not succeeded in reassuring the inhabitants about their security concerns which is causing them to flee.
 
This crisis calls for immediate attention and action on our part. We need assistance from all possible quarters – government bodies, non-profit organizations and even individuals who can provide either financial help or physical resources such as food, clothing or shelter for these displaced people.
 
Would appreciate any guidance or support you could render in this hour of need – every bit counts! Also please share this information with others who might be able to help anyway.

Armed Bandits attack Gidan Dusun village of Sarkin Baura Ward of Kaura Namoda LGA. They killed one person and twenty were kidnapped also one was injured. Another attack occurred in Daura Birnin Tsaba of Zurmi LGA. The bandits killed four people including two security personnel and nine people sustained injuries.

Many people were displaced in Kaura Namoda and Zurmi town and are taking shelter in Tsafe town.  There have been incessant bandit attacks in many communities in Zamfara leading to the loss of lives and preventing farmers from accessing their farmlands thereby causing a food crisis.

field_reports.description:
The Mangu Local government has been experiencing armed conflict for the last 6 months between farmers and herders. For the first time, it has escalated to the main town of Mangu and other surrounding villages leaving several people either wounded, dead, or houses destroyed. The recent one started on 22nd January 2024 at about 19 hours and continued unabated to 23rd January and today 24th January 2024. Many houses were burnt and raised down, and casualties and deaths were also recorded as the result of farmer’s headers clashes which metamorphosed into religious conflict in Mangu town.

120 injured

55 deaths ( 30 in Kwahaslalek village of Mairana axis )

250 houses were burnt and destroyed.

About 8000 Affected population

IDP Camps

Pilot primary 2000

Madina Mosque 850

Central Mosque 600

Some IDPs in Neighboring Bauchi state at Boto, Lere, and Kardam, have no assessment yet.

The conflict started on 23rd January 2024 as a result of chieftaincy conflict. The area has been witnessing continuous conflict in the last 15 years between loyalists to Shehu and Lot militias. Preliminary reports by volunteers of the Nigerian Red Cross Society after an on-the-spot assessment indicate that about 3 individuals lost their lives as a result of the attacks and 7 people injured while about 1000 already discplaced from their homes.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: In week 11 of 2024, 35 new confirmed cases have been reported in Bauchi, Taraba, Edo, Ondo, Plateau, Benue, Cross River, and Ebonyi States. Cumulatively from week 1 to 11, 2024, 142 deaths have been reported with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 18.5%. In total for 2024, 27 States have recorded at least one confirmed case across 123 Local Government Areas. Sixty-two (62%) of all confirmed Lassa fever cases were reported from these three states (Ondo, Edo, and Bauchi) while 38% were reported from 24 states with confirmed Lassa fever cases. Of the 62% confirmed cases, Ondo reported 23%, Edo 23%, and Bauchi 16% • The predominant age group affected is 31-40 years (Range: 1 to 98 years, Median Age: 32 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:0.9 . The number of suspected cases has progressively increased compared to that reported for the same period in 2023. In the same epi week, another Healthcare worker was affected causing more scare among health care workers.
field_reports.description:
The Lassa Fever outbreak in Nigeria keeps escalating with a cumulative 4, 726 cases since week 1 of 2024. Sadly, 142 deaths have been recorded so far and 31 healthcare workers have been affected in 27 states including the FCT.

The worst affected states are Bauchi, Taraba, Edo, Ondo, Plateau, Benue, Cross River, Rivers, Anambra, and Ebonyi States with 123 Local Government Areas. Although Lassa fever disease is endemic in Nigeria, a case fatality rate (CFR) of 18.5% has raised a lot of concerns, especially around late diagnosis and reporting which has led to increased fatality.

Comparing the present situation with the 2023 outbreak, the number of suspected cases in 2024 has progressively increased (4,726) compared to that reported for the same period in 2023, which was 3, 361.

The National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Incident Management System has been activated to coordinate response at all levels at the Emergency Operations Centre (EOC). So far, the response has been coordinated through 8 pillars namely: Coordination, Research, Risk Communication, Surveillance, Case Management, Logistics, Laboratory, Infection Prevention and Control and Safe burial.

The NCDC has highlighted the following as major challenges and gaps in response-

Late presentation of cases leading to an increase in CFR
Poor health-seeking behavior due to the high cost of treatment and clinical management of Lassa fever
Poor environmental sanitation conditions observed in high-burden communities
Poor awareness and lack of community engagement in high-burden communities
Poor IPC measures among health workers especially at the Primary Health Care level
Inadequate Psychosocial services to the community health workers who have rejected patients as a result of fear of infection and consequently death.
In recognition of the grassroots presence and the strength and capacity of the Red Cross in community engagement, active case search, and health promotion, the Government is requesting the Red Cross support to bridge the gap in response, enhance community awareness, and promote early detection and presentation of cases to reduce the mortality rates and improve health and wellbeing.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Biological Emergency - 01-2024 - Lassa Fever Emergency #2 (2024-02-13)
field_reports.description:
Effects of the Hazard

Lassa fever is a viral infection carried by the multimammate rat (Mastomys natalensis), one of the most common mice in equatorial Africa found across much of sub-Saharan Africa. The illness was first discovered in Nigeria when two missionary nurses got infected with the virus in 1969. Its name is derived from the village of Lassa where it was first documented. Lassa fever is predominantly reported in Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea and Nigeria but, because of the Mastomys rat's high prevalence in neighbouring countries, these areas are also at risk. Once a Mastomys rat is infected, it can excrete the virus in its urine, potentially for the rest of its life. This makes the spread of the disease worryingly easy when added to the fact that this species, like other rats, breeds easily and inhabits human homes. The most common method of transmission is the consumption or inhalation of rat urine or faeces, through food and/or water. Lassa fever can also be spread through cuts and open sores. Because the rats live in and around human habitation, they often come into contact with foodstuffs. The rats themselves are sometimes eaten and the disease can be spread during their preparation. Person-to-person transmission is possible via blood, tissue, secretions or excretions, but not through touch. Lassa fever can also be passed between patients and staff at poorly equipped hospitals where sterilization and protective clothing is not standard.

Current Situation and affected population

Cumulatively from week 4, 2024, 48 deaths have been reported with a case fatality rate (CFR) of 18.6 % which is higher than the CFR for the same period in 2023 (17.9%) In total for 2024, 18 States have recorded at least one confirmed case across 60 Local Government Areas. 

Seventy-two (72%) of all confirmed Lassa fever cases were reported from these three states (Ondo, Edo, and Bauchi) while 28% were reported from 15 states with confirmed Lassa fever cases. Of the 72% confirmed cases, Ondo reported 25%, Edo 24%, and Bauchi 24%.The predominant age group affected is 21-30 years (Range: 1 to 98 years, Median Age: 31.5 years). The male-to-female ratio for confirmed cases is 1:1.The number of suspected cases increased compared to that reported for the same period in 2023. One new Healthcare worker was affected in the reporting week 4. National Lassa fever multi-partner, multi-sectoral Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) activated to coordinate the response activities at all levels on the 14th of January 2024.

With the increasing number of Lassa fever cases reported from several States across the country, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) which is the coordinating agency has activated the National Lassa fever Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) for coordination of response. A letter of notification of Lassa fever EOC Activation has also been sent to 36 states and FCT to activate the state EOC. The NCDC is collaborating with the World Health Organization (WHO), Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Irua Specialist Teaching Hospital, African Field Epidemiology Network, US Centres for Disease Control and other agencies, in supporting the response in the affected States.

field_reports.description:
Lassa Fever is an epidemic-prone disease for immediate Integrated Disease notification but case fatality rates range from 3% to 42% (and over the last two years has remained
between 20% and 25%). Historically, outbreaks occur during the dry season (November to April);
however, in recent years, cases have also occurred during the rainy season.

Lassa Fever (LF) remains a health burden and endemic in Nigeria, and the toll in case fatality remains unabated over several decades. The disease results in 500,000 cases annually and approximately 5000 deaths in endemic West Africa. Although the overall case fatality rate is 1% mortality can be as high as 15–20% in hospitalized LF patients and up to 50% during outbreaks

In 80% of human cases, the disease is asymptomatic, but in the remaining 20% a complicated course leading to death may result in nonspecific symptoms indistinguishable from other Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers (VHFs) such as Ebola and Marburg. Typically, human infection results from contact with secretions and excretions of infected rats and other infected persons through respiratory or gastrointestinal tracts. Inhalation of aerosolized infective viral LASV particles is the most significant means of exposure.
 The current situation is exacerbated by stigma and discrimination against infected individuals which poses significant barriers, negatively affecting access to care and treatment. These can substantially increase the suffering of infected individuals and can be strong disincentives for individuals in seeking prompt medical care

results.summary:
Lassa Fever is an epidemic-prone disease for immediate Integrated Disease notification but case fatality rates range from 3% to 42% (and over the last two years has remained
between 20% and 25%). Historically, outbreaks occur during the dry season (November to April);
however, in recent years, cases have also occurred during the rainy season.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Other - 01-2024 - Explosion In Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria
field_reports.description:
On the evening of January 16th, a significant explosion occurred at Deji Oyelese Close in Old Bodija, Ibadan, resulting in widespread impact on the surrounding area. The explosion has left a trail of devastation, affecting more than 80 houses in the vicinity. The current context is one of emergency response and recovery efforts as authorities and rescue teams mobilize to address the aftermath.

The blast has taken a toll on the local population, with 77 individuals reported as injured at the time of initial reporting. These casualties have been promptly transferred to health facilities for medical attention. The severity of injuries varies, and the full extent of the impact on the affected individuals is yet to be assessed.

The affected population is experiencing a range of challenges, including physical injuries, trauma, and potential displacement due to damage to their homes. The explosion has not only caused immediate harm but may also have long-term implications for the well-being and livelihoods of those residing in the affected area.

Emergency services are actively engaged in managing the situation, providing medical assistance, and ensuring the safety of the affected population.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
On January 12, 2024, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) as reported by  DatelineHealthAfrica, issued a public advisory on the increased risk of cerebrospinal meningitis (CSM) outbreak in Nigeria.
The highest burden of CSM in Nigeria is said to occur in the ‘Meningitis Belt', which includes all 19 states in the northern region, the Federal Capital Territory (FCT) and some southern states such as Bayelsa, Cross River, Delta, Ekiti, Ogun, Ondo and Osun.
Information reaching the Nigerian Red Cross Society reveals that 152 persons have been reported dead from suspected CSM cases in 4 States of Yobe, Gombe, Bauchi and Jigawa with 772  suspected cases reported in 26 LGAs cumulatively.
The Yobe State Governor in the Guardian New paper of February 29, 2024 was quoted to have reported a total of 214 suspected CSM with20 deaths said to be from 4 schools in 3 LGAs. The suspected cases were said to have been evacuated from the schools to Potiskum specialist hospital for isolation and treatment. 
In Gombe State, the Commissioner for Health in a press release was quoted by the source to have reported that 95 suspected cases and 2 deaths have been recorded in the State from 2 LGAs as at the time of the press release - March 1, 2024. Nigeria Centre for Disease Control EPI report for week 9 shows 199 suspected cases, 61 deaths and 7 confirmed cumulative cases of CSM reported from 7 Local Government Areas and 24 Wards. 
Jigawa State has reported 264 suspected cases and 65 deaths from 14 LGAs
It is important to note that reports are still being expected from all the affected States and this field report will be updated as the reports roll-in
field_reports.description:
CSM is an epidemic–prone disease with infections reported all year round across Nigeria. The disease is caused by acute inflammation of the coverings of the brain and spinal cord and weather conditions like the dry season with dust, winds and cold nights aided by overcrowding, poor ventilation and frequent upper respiratory tract infections increases the risk of contracting the disease. Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, a thin layer of the connective tissue that covers the brain and the spinal cord. If due to an infection, this inflammation can be caused by a variety of organisms - bacteria, viruses, parasites or fungi. Injuries and certain drugs can also cause such inflammation. Bacterial meningitis is of significant public health importance because; It has a high morbidity and mortality, can be epidemic prone depending on the type of bacteria, and is both treatable and preventable.
The CSM disease can affect persons of all ages and gender. Cumulatively Epi-Summary as at 31st December 2023, a total of 115 suspected cases including 16 deaths (CFR 13.9%) have been reported from 15 states in this 2023/2024 CSM season. A total of 37 samples were collected (32.17%) from 115 suspected cases from beginning of the outbreak, and 12 cases confirmed (32% positivity rate). The 5 -14-year-old age group was the most affected and 53% of the total suspected cases were Males. Eity-two percent (82%) of all suspected cases were from five (5) states – Jigawa (53 cases), katsina (21 cases), Oyo (15 cases) and Kano (5 cases). Eighteen LGAs across four states, Jigawa (11), Katsina (4), Oyo (2) and Kebbi (1), reported more than two suspected cases each in 2023/2024 CSM season.file:///C:/Users/user/Downloads/An%20Update%20of%20Meningitis%20Outbreak%20in%20Nigeria_210923_38.pdf

results.summary:
The severe malnutrition crisis in northeast Nigeria has been exacerbated by ongoing conflict, displacement, and limited access to essential
services. Children are particularly vulnerable, facing heightened risks of morbidity and mortality. The healthcare system, already strained
by high demand, is struggling to cope with the escalating needs, highlighting an urgent need for increased support and intervention to
address the malnutrition emergency.


Humanitarian organizations in northeast Nigeria have issued urgent warnings due to a dramatic surge in malnutrition among children in
Borno, Adamawa, and Yobe (BAY) States. Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) which is leading the case management pillar of the Nutrition
cluster in Nigeria, has observed a significant increase in admissions of severely malnourished children with life-threatening complications
across seven northern Nigerian states, including the BAY states, with some areas experiencing admissions double those of 2023.
The BAY states' nutrition sector reported a 63 percent increase in admissions of children with complicated severe acute malnutrition
(SAM) between January and April 2024, compared to the same period in 2023. The worsening nutrition situation has overwhelmed the
healthcare system, with bed occupancy rates reaching 100 percent well before the expected peak of the lean season.
According to the UNOCHA report, In April 2024 alone, MSF admitted 1,250 severely malnourished children with complications to its
inpatient therapeutic feeding centers across the BAY states. This number is double the admissions recorded in April 2023. By the end of
May 2024, MSF's facilities in these states were accommodating 350 patients, far exceeding the 200-bed capacity initially set for the peak of
the lean season, which spans from June to August.


In addition, Nutrition surveillance data from April among displaced populations from remote and hard-to-reach communities in the BAY
states revealed an alarming 18 percent prevalence of SAM and Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) among children aged 6-59 months.
The data also indicated a 1.2 percent increase in the overall prevalence of malnutrition and a 0.9 percent increase in SAM cases among
children compared to March 2024. This trend underscores a critical and deteriorating nutrition situation that requires an immediate and
collaborative response.


Since January, humanitarian partners in the BAY states have been providing either food or cash transfers to support displaced people
living in camps or with host communities, as well as vulnerable host populations. With diminishing resources, partners have reached over
1.1 million vulnerable people with food assistance out of 4.8 million in need this lean season. Despite the alarming situation, the overall
humanitarian response remains inadequate. Funding for the ongoing humanitarian response in the BAY states remains a major
challenge. As of 12 June, the 2024 Humanitarian Response Plan, which needs $926.5 million, is only 20.5 percent funded. The nutrition
sector has reported that the ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) and ready-to-use supplementary food (RUSF) pipelines may break in
July due to an increase in acute malnutrition admissions during the first quarter of 2024.


Furthermore, the outbreaks of AWD and measles in the BAY states have exacerbated the malnutrition crisis, leading to higher rates of SAM, increased morbidity, and mortality, decreased nutrient absorption, exacerbated nutritional deficiencies, and a strained healthcare
system. Children who were already moderately malnourished are quickly deteriorating to severe malnutrition due to the additional
health burdens, leading to a significant rise in the number of children suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). Lack of access to
healthcare services, especially in hard-to-reach communities has led to complications such as severe dehydration and contributed to
poor management and control of AWD outbreaks, allowing the disease to spread more rapidly within communities.

To mitigate these effects, integrated health and nutrition interventions are essential, including disease prevention, nutritional support,
and strengthening of healthcare systems. The NRCS, through its grassroots presence of community-based skilled volunteer structures,
seeks to complement the efforts of the Government to strengthen Health and Nutrition Services through Community-Based Surveillance
(CBS), Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE), Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF), Protection, Gender, and Inclusion
(PGI) and WASH in Adamawa, Yobe and Borno States.
results.name: NGA: 2024 Severe Acute Malnutrition

field_reports.summary: NGA: Civil Unrest - 01-2024 - Gunmen Attack in Plateau State #2 (2024-01-21)
field_reports.description:
On the 17th of January, a new wave of conflict erupted in the Bokkos, Barkin Ladi, and Mangu Local Government Areas (LGAs) of the Plateau State, specifically impacting the villages of Majakata, Cikam, and Shoron in Bokkos LGA, as well as Mararraban Kantoma in Barkin Ladi LGA. The situation has intensified, further exacerbating existing tensions in the affected areas.

The recent conflict has resulted in a significant toll on the communities, with reports indicating a distressing number of casualties and an increase in displacement. The violence has left 13 individuals injured and, tragically, claimed the lives of 9 people. Additionally, the conflict has forced 400 individuals to become new internally displaced persons (IDPs).

As of the latest updates, the security situation remains precarious, with ongoing tensions contributing to an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty. The conflict has disrupted normalcy in the affected villages, posing challenges to the residents' safety and well-being. Efforts to address and de-escalate the situation are underway by  the government, but the region remains on edge.

The local population, particularly in the villages of Majakata, Cikam, Shoron, and Mararraban Kantoma, is directly affected by the conflict. These communities now face the harsh reality of injuries, loss of lives, and displacement. The sudden upheaval has disrupted their daily lives, instilling a sense of vulnerability and insecurity.

The consequences of the conflict are profound, with families mourning the loss of loved ones and individuals grappling with injuries. The newly displaced individuals, numbering 400, find themselves in precarious circumstances, with immediate needs for shelter, food, and medical attention. The social fabric of the affected communities has been strained as they navigate the aftermath of the conflict and strive to rebuild their lives.

On the night of Saturday, 23rd December 2023, a series of violent coordinated attacks by suspected gunmen erupted in Lisha community, extending to neighboring communities such as Kwahasnat, KambarIpelli, Mutfyan, among others. The incident unfolded at approximately 22:45 hours, leading to a devastating impact on the affected areas.

Preliminary reports by volunteers of the Nigerian Red Cross Society after an on-the-spot assessment indicate that not fewer than 213 individuals lost their lives as a result of the attacks. The casualties are spread across multiple communities affected by the violence.

Approximately 100 individuals sustained severe injuries and have been evacuated to medical facilities for urgent treatment. The injured have been transported to Jos University Teaching Hospital (JUTH) and Bokkos Medical Center to receive medical attention. The assessment also showed that around 200 individuals with minor injuries were treated and subsequently discharged after receiving medical care.

Immediate response efforts focused on the evacuation and treatment of the injured. Security forces and emergency response teams are currently on-site to stabilize the situation, provide necessary security, and offer support to the affected communities. The government of Plateau State has also appealed for coordination efforts to ensure the effective delivery of aid, medical assistance, and logistical support to those impacted by the incident.

As of the latest reports, the situation remains volatile and fluid, with ongoing efforts to stabilize the affected areas. Security forces and emergency response teams are actively engaged in restoring order, providing security, and supporting affected communities. This attack has left more than 11,000 people already displaced, and not fewer than 221 houses burned, with properties worth millions of Naira destroyed.

While the casualty figures continue to rise, the coordinated attacks on 23 villages in Bokkos and Barkin Ladi local government areas of Plateau State have created immediate humanitarian needs such as medical supplies, food, and shelter to support the affected communities.

The affected population is grappling with profound psychological trauma due to the loss of loved ones, witnessing violence, and the overall disruption of their community and daily lives. Also, the displaced individuals and those directly affected by the violence are in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, including shelter, food, and medical care. The disrupted infrastructure and security situation pose significant challenges to the effective delivery of aid.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Epidemic - 2023-07 - Anthrax Outbreak in Nigeria
field_reports.description:
The Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (FMARD) has confirmed one case of Anthrax disease in a mixed livestock farm in Niger State. This is the first animal case to be reported in Nigeria since the beginning of the West Africa outbreak in Ghana in June 2023. On 13th July 2023, the sudden deaths of livestock in this farm with eight (8) mortality was reported. In addition, the animals who died were observed to have been bleeding from external orifices without blood clotting. The Nigerian Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) has said that anthrax disease may have spread to every part of the country. The NCDC said this hours after the Federal Government through the Ministry of Agriculture confirmed the first case of the disease in Niger state.
The case was in a multi-specie animal farm comprising of cattle, sheep and goats located at Gajiri, in Suleja Local Government Area, Niger State, where some of the animals had symptoms including oozing of blood from their body openings – anus, nose, eyes, and ears.
According to the Spokesperson of FMARD, there were significant movements of animals in the area of the last religious feast. The areas are called down south, and it’s possible that in that region where animals are infected may have made their way into the country. Most especially for animals that were brought in across the borders. So, in this context, there may be other animals with it.
The country’s Ministry of Health also expressed worry that anthrax has spread across the 36 states and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT). Stating that it is possible that the disease is currently across the country and likely other cases that are yet to be notified.

The signs of anthrax-infected animals include the oozing of blood from their body openings – (anus, nose, eyes, and ears), and high fever; it should be noted that, in many cases, the sign is not visible and leads to sudden death.

Following the report, samples were collected on 14th July 2023 from multiple species in this livestock farm and transported to the National Veterinary Research Institute (NVRI), VOM, Plateau State for testing and the results were positive for anthrax.

Further investigation is also ongoing to trace the source of the infection and to identify the spread to other farms and humans. Though human exposure has been reported, there are no reports so far of human symptoms or mortality. The FMARD and the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) are currently working closely with the Niger State Ministries of Health and Agriculture to identify, isolate and follow up all exposed persons.

field_reports.summary: NGA: Flood - 2023-06 - Flash flooding due to adverse weather condition
field_reports.description:
According to social media platform and the local news 116 houses were submerged in Trademore Estate of Lugbe community following heavy rains that hit the Federal Capital Territory around mid morning (23/06/2023). The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has confirmed this information while debunking the unconfirmed report of 1 death. The NRCS has activated its Branch structures and have deployed volunteers in the locality to provide rapid assessment reports of the situation on the ground. The NRCS is working closely with movement partners in country to work out a response to the flooding situation. 

As at the time of filing this report, stakeholders responding to the flood on the estate are NEMA, Fire Service, FCT FEMA, Red Cross and Federal Ministry of Environment-Flood department.
